edge: Ruby Rossi is the child of deaf adults and only hearing member of her family, making her a CODA (Children Of Deaf Adults).
Ruby Rossi pursues her aspirations to become a singer.
Deaf characters in the movie communicate using American Sign Language.
The movie is filmed on location in Gloucester, Massachusetts.
Eugenio Derbez plays a supporting role in the movie.
Troy Kotsur, a deaf actor, plays a supporting role in the movie.
Ferdia Walsh-Peelo plays a supporting role in the movie.
Daniel Durant, a deaf actor, makes his feature film debut in the movie.
Marlee Matlin, an Oscar-winning deaf actress, plays a supporting role in the movie.
CODA had its world premiere at the Sundance Film Festival.
Apple acquired distribution rights for CODA through their streaming service, Apple TV+.
CODA won the prestigious Best Picture award at the 94th Academy Awards.
CODA received all three of its Academy Award nominations, which were for Best Picture, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Adapted Screenplay.

node_2: the lord of the rings: the return of the king
edge: CODA became the seventh film in history to win every award for which it was nominated, joining a prestigious group that includes Wings (1927), Grand Hotel (1932), It Happened One Night (1934), Gigi (1958), and The Last Emperor (1987). This group also includes The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003).
At the 94th Academy Awards, Kotsur won the highly coveted Best Supporting Actor award.
With his win at the 94th Academy Awards, Kotsur became the first male deaf actor to take home this prestigious honor.
CODA made history by becoming the first film ever distributed by a streaming service to win the Academy Award for Best Picture.
In another groundbreaking first, CODA became the first film ever premiered at the Sundance Film Festival to win the Academy Award for Best Picture.
In addition to its many Academy Awards, CODA also won the prestigious Producers Guild of America Award for Best Theatrical Motion Picture.
The talented cast of CODA also received high praise, winning the Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture.
The film's outstanding screenplay also earned it the BAFTA Award for Best Adapted Screenplay, as well as the Writers Guild of America Award for Best Adapted Screenplay.
Mr. V encourages Ruby to audition for Berklee College of Music, his alma mater.
Mr. V offers Ruby private lessons to prepare for Berklee College of Music.
Ruby's increasing commitments to the family business cause her to be late to Mr. V's lessons.
Mr. V grows irritated with Ruby's constant tardiness and chastises her for wasting his time and not caring enough about music.
When Frank and Leo sail with a federal fishing observer on board, who does not know in advance that they are deaf.
The boat is intercepted by the Coast Guard after failing to respond to ship horns and radio calls.
When Ruby is off swimming with Miles, Frank and Leo sail without her.
Frank and Leo are fined and have their fishing licenses suspended for negligence.
Ruby tells Frank and Leo that she can't always interpret for them and she was not at fault when they appeal and get their license back.
Leo reacts angrily, insisting that they can manage without Ruby as she truly has talent.
Ruby announces to the family business that she is forgoing college and will join the business full-time.
Ruby's parents are supportive, but Leo reacts angrily when she makes this decision.

Written and directed by Sian Heder, CODA is an adaptation of the French-language film La Famille Bélier. Producer Philippe Rousselet, who was one of the original film's producers, had the right to do a remake.
Set in Gloucester, CODA was chosen by director Sian Heder for its picturesque and working-class qualities.
CODA is a remake of the French-language film La Famille Bélier, which was released in 2014 and was successful at the French box office.
Heder chose Gloucester for CODA because of its combination of picturesque and working-class qualities that are typical of New England.
In the process of writing the script for CODA, director Sian Heder was helped by two deaf collaborators known as 'ASL masters', Alexandria Wailes and Anne Tomasetti.
40% of the script for CODA is written in American Sign Language, as director Sian Heder learned ASL while writing the script.
CODA was developed and produced by the film production partnership formed by Pathé Films and Vendôme Group, which aims to develop and produce English-language films.

Several consultants and a fisherman educated Marlee Heder, the actress playing the lead role in the film, in local fishing practices as part of her preparation for the film. The Gloucester Fishermen's Wives Association also provided consultation during the development process.

Marlee Matlin, an award-winning and internationally known actress, threatened to drop out of the film unless deaf actors were cast for the remaining deaf characters. The financiers initially resisted this but ultimately relented.
Director Kenneth Lonergan provided feedback to Marlee Heder as part of her preparation for the film, which was set in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts.
To prepare for the film, Marlee Heder observed a fish processing plant.
Marlee Heder received feedback from the local harbormaster about how authorities would raid a boat as part of her preparation for the film.

Matlin described her interest in getting CODA made, 'I felt that audiences would really see deaf people in a film ... There are so many levels for people to identify with and, for people with no connection, who have never met a deaf person, to see sign language, to see deaf people in normal, day-to-day settings ... People think that deaf people are monolithic in how they approach life. And this film bursts that myth ... But to burst that myth, it had to be told as authentically as possible. And it’s strange because studios clearly have the ability to greenlight a film and cast whomever they want, and there continues to be a lack of awareness that you can tell universal stories with deaf characters.'

Matlin described her interest in getting CODA made, 'There are so many levels for people to identify with and, for people with no connection, who have never met a deaf person, to see sign language, to see deaf people in normal, day-to-day settings ... People think that deaf people are monolithic in how they approach life. And this film bursts that myth ...'

Matlin described her interest in getting CODA made, '... It had to be told as authentically as possible. And it’s strange because studios clearly have the ability to greenlight a film and cast whomever they want, and there continues to be a lack of awareness that you can tell universal stories with deaf characters.'
Matlin described her interest in getting CODA made, 'People think that deaf people are monolithic in how they approach life. And this film bursts that myth ...'

Kotsur said, 'You have to think a little bit outside the box and present more opportunities, instead of just having two options ... You know, you write this script because somebody’s deaf, or I’m writing it because it’s a character that happens to be deaf. There’s a distinction there.'
Heder connected with the deaf community in nearby Boston to secure the ASL interpreters for on-set communication.

node_2: hearing member of the deaf family
edge: The director auditioned hundreds of teenage girls before casting Emilia Jones as the hearing member of the deaf family.
Heder also chose to cast Eugenio Derbez as the girl's choirmaster, seeing him as a fit for her 'amalgamation of Heder's college rhythm teacher and her high school drama and English teachers'.
The film was shot on location in Gloucester, Massachusetts, in the middle of 2019.
The film was shot on location in Gloucester, Massachusetts
In the film, the family lives in what WBUR's The ARTery described as a 'creteaky clapboard cottage [with] a yard jammed with boats, traps, and nets'
During location scouting, Heder came across what she found to be the ideal house for the family home and received permission from its residents to use it as a filming location.
The choirmaster's home was a Victorian-style house on the sea
Heder had visited family friends multiple times in her childhood, and they allowed her to film there.
A fisherman who educated Heder in local fishing practices allowed his fishing trawler to be used as a film set.
Scenes set in a flooded quarry were filmed at the Steel Derrick quarry in Rockport, Massachusetts.
Scenes set in a flooded quarry were filmed at the Steel Derrick quarry in Rockport, Massachusetts.
Marius de Vries composed the film's soundtrack and compiled and co-produced the album with Nicholai Baxter.
Marius de Vries composed the film's soundtrack and compiled and co-produced the album with Nicholai Baxter.
Marius de Vries composed the film's soundtrack and compiled and co-produced the album with Nicholai Baxter.
Most of the incorporated songs in the film were recorded live and sung by Emilia Jones, accompanied by the CODA choir.
Most of the incorporated songs in the film were recorded live and sung by Ferdia Walsh-Peelo, accompanied by the CODA choir.
Most of the incorporated songs in the film were recorded live and sung by Emilia Jones, Ferdia Walsh-Peelo, and the CODA choir.
The soundtrack album features an original song sung by Emilia Jones, 'Beyond the Shore,' which is played during the end credits of the film.
The soundtrack album was released by Republic Records on August 13, 2021, coinciding with the film's release.
CODA had its world premiere on January 28, 2021, at the 2021 Sundance Film Festival.
CODA was screened as part of the festival's US Dramatic Competition at the 2021 Sundance Film Festival.
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, CODA was screened virtually at the 2021 Sundance Film Festival.
In 2022, CODA won the Academy Award for Best Picture, making it the only modern-day film to receive this honor without being released on home video formats.

According to available data as of March 20, 2022, CODA had been streamed in 973,000 households in the United States, with approximately 375,000 views since the Oscar nomination announcements on February 8.

Initially rated R for language, as displayed in subtitles during deaf characters' dialogue in some scenes, the film was ultimately reduced to PG-13 due to strong sexual content and language, and drug use after several 'back-and-forths' and fights with the MPA months before its official release. The film's producers explained that vulgar sign language is a part of their culture but questioned whether audiences were ready.
The film was streamed exclusively on Apple TV+

Benjamin Lee's Guardian-based three-star review stated that Coda is a mostly likable concoction, but one that's just too formulaic and ultimately rather calculated to secure the emotional response it so desperately wants by the big finale.

Benjamin Lee's Guardian-based three-star review also mentioned that Coda is mostly likable concoction, but one that's just too conventional and ultimately rather calculated to secure the emotional response it so desperately wants by the big finale.
Owen Gilberman from Variety stated that Coda brings this all off with such sincerity and precision, and also praised Jones and Kotsur's performances.

Writing for The New York Times, editor Jeannette Catsoulis stated that an openhearted embrace of deaf culture elevates this otherwise conventional tale of a talented teenager caught between ambition and loyalty.

opined that "CODA faithfully works its way through a checklist of tropes from high school comedies, disability dramas, musical-prodigy and inspiring-teacher narratives, coming-of-age tales about young people struggling to declare independence from overbearing families and indie chronicles of blue-collar America"

called it an "old-fashioned movie that adheres to admittedly familiar principles of storytelling and emotional stakes, but by way of such a winning cast, evocative atmosphere and genuine tone that its impossible not to love"

wrote "It's not that Heder doesn't embrace the aforesaid conventions for all their comforting worth — she does. But by twisting the formula and placing this recognizable story inside a new, perhaps even groundbreaking setting with such loving, acutely observed specificity, she pulls off nothing short of a heartwarming miracle with her film."

CODA is a small family drama that was filled with light-hearted moments and left plenty of tears in their eyes.
This small indie movie CODA surprised everyone and won over so many people, making it one of the most crowd-pleasing movies of the 2020s.
It certainly deserves way more credit and is groundbreaking in its representation of disability, as per MovieWeb's list of the '20 Most Underrated Films of the Last 5 Years.'

The film's depiction of the hearing child interpreting for her parents even in settings where professional interpreters would be required by the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, such as a court hearing and medical appointments, received widespread criticism as being misrepresentative.

It ranked number 5 on Screen Rant's list of 'The 10 Best Movies of the 2020s (So Far)' and number 18 on Collider's list of 'The 20 Best Drama Movies of the 2020s So Far', as per two popular movie ranking lists.
CODA was one of 28 films that received the ReFrame Stamp for 2021, awarded by the gender equity coalition ReFrame for films that are proven to have gender-balanced hiring.
The film CODA was given the Seal of Authentic Representation from the Ruderman Family Foundation for Matlin's and Durant's roles as Ruby's mother and brother.
In an effort to keep the film relevant after awards season, its producers plan to team up with Deaf West Theatre to develop a stage musical adaptation of the film.
Like Deaf West's production of Spring Awakening, the musical will incorporate both signing in American Sign Language and live singing.
DJ Kurs, Deaf West's artistic director, expressed excitement for the project:

In 2014, Rousselet was asked about making a stage version of La Famille Bélier but prioritized making CODA and forming a relationship with Deaf West first. Rousselet further remarked that the musical has everything to make a beautiful production.

Rousselet wanted to prioritize making CODA and forming a relationship with Deaf West first.
In 2018, Kotsur hoped that the musical would have its initial staging within two years and seemed to suggest that he might reprise his role as Frank in the production.
In 2018, Kotsur hoped to have Matlin and Durant also reprise their roles as Jackie and Leo, respectively, along with Kotsur in the La Famille Bélier musical.
In August 2024, Deaf West Theatre announced its 2024–25 season and officially confirmed that the La Famille Bélier musical is still in the works.

In August 2024, Deaf West Theatre announced its 2024–25 season and Kurs noted his desire to have Matlin and Durant also reprise their roles as Jackie and Leo, respectively, along with Kotsur in the La Famille Bélier musical.
